entry.p: Roderick Long reflects on the idea of individualist anarchism as a universalization of aristocracy. He quotes George Woodcock:

blockquote.p: In reality the ideal of anarchism, far from being democracy carried to its logical end, is much nearer to aristocracy universalized and purified.

entry.p: Or as Shelley said: "The man of virtuous soul commands not, nor obeys."
Roderick also quotes Ernest Lesigne on socialism vs. anarchism:

blockquote.p: Both desire equality. One by lowering heads that are too high. The other by raising heads that are too low.

entry.p: His long quote from Anne Rice's novel The Vampire Lestat is quite intriguing, too. (And he's got me quite interested in reading Oscar Wilde's The Soul of Man Under Socialism.)
